comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Lee Enfield Carbine adapted for the RIC
Lee Enfield Mk1* carbines or Lee Metford cavalry carbines converted to Enfield rifling; 21 inch barrel, nose cap adapted to take the Pattern 88 knife bayonet. Small six-round magazines. 11,000 were supplied by the War Office as a free issue to the RIC between March 1904 and 1914. The new carbine was first issued to the Reserve Force at Dublin's Phoenix Park Depot in March 1904, before being distributed across the county forces. It replaced the Martini Henry carbine and at the same time replaced the existing long bayonet with the shorter knife pattern. By July 1904 the new rifle had been issued to counties Cavan and Carlow, and special training regarding the mechanism of the new rifles had been given to the RIC Musketry Instructors. In January 1905 Kings county had been supplied, and it was noted that Morris Tubes had been privately purchased by some of the men for practice. County Monaghan did not take possession of the carbines until April 1905. In September 1920 the RIC wrote to the Ministry of Munitions of War to communicate their desire to sell as scrap approximately 10,000 of these carbines, which were to be replaced with the modern SMLE rifle. They were shipped to the Royal Small Arms Factory at Enfield Lock around November or December 1920, together with around 1.1 million rounds of MkVI ammunition (ref: National Archives file MUN 4/6028).

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: Going by the collar insignia of the officer on parade the bearskins could be those of the Grenadier Guards. And we have a Royal Marine with the trumpet and the rest possiblly the Kings Royal Rifle Corps. You can see the uniform here www.geocities.ws/dblatcher/krrc17551936.html but as they are wearing their great coats I am going by the head gear. They are now part of the Royal Green Jackets I believe.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: The hat badge could be the Grenadier Guards but doesn't look like the Irish Guards

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: Another picture showing the officers uniforms. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:King%27s_Royal_Rifle_Corps_by_...

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: In 1900, 75 men from the regiment (Grenadier Guards) were used to raise a fourth Guards regiment, known as the Irish Guards in honour of the role that Irish regiments had played in the fighting in South Africa.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland], [http://www.flickr.com/photos/shanekillen] I think it looks like an Irish guard hat badge. irishhistoricalmilitaria.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/01/d...

comment.author: 8468254@N02

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Here's the fusilier collar badge: www.britishmilitarybadges.co.uk/images/huuj%20257.JPG. I'm not convinced that's what we're seeing.

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] The Irish Guards use the shamrock as their collar badge and though they have a cap badge they don't use it on their bearskins which instead have a blue plume on the RHS. I think it is Royal Dublin Fusiliers, as they are not a guards regiment I hadn't realised that they wore bearskin, and looking at some photos they did use a badge on their bearskins. In fact it's far more likely to be them than the Grenadier Guards.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/shanekillen] I think you're right. That sort of zigzag thing could well be the elephant and tiger motif: www.sellmymilitaria.com/site/components/com_djclassifieds...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Incidentally, does anyone know why the fusiliers all seem to have a bombard as an emblem instead of a fusil? If there's one thing you can't rifle it's a bombard!

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content:
I don't know whether it's the pace, or I'm still struggling with the "new Flickr", but I'm not sure I am keeping-up with the consensus building these days. I think we are saying:
* Dublin Castle - DEFINITELY * ~1905 - PROBABLY * Changing of guard - DEFINITELY * On the left is Royal Dublin Fusiliers - PROBABLY * On the right are Rifles - PROBABLY (Either RIR, RUR, London Irish Rifles, or some other Rifles regiment) * Handover "direction" - UNKNOWN (Could be RDF handing over to Rifles. Or vice versa. We dunno yet)

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/shanekillen/] It could very well be the Kings Royal Rifle Corps. The hat they are wearing is an actual Busby, sealskin for other ranks, lambswool for officers. The Royal Irish rifles also wore this type of head gear at the time.

comment._content: Could it be 1879-ish? The one on the left with the pointy white hat reminds me of the Zulu War uniforms, www.thehistorybunker.co.uk/acatalog/British_Army_Victoria... (the red one). I'm thinking Royal Engineers, maybe 1890s-ish? It's got to be late 1800s...

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Um, your friends at the Irish National Archives seem to think it's 1911... www.census.nationalarchives.ie/exhibition/dublin/governme... they have your photo about 3/4 of the way down...

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Definitely not Royal Irish rangers, they did not exist before 1968. I would lean towards Royal Irish Rifles myself but theres just not enough detail to be certain. The officer in the bearskin hat on the left appears to be Royal Irish Fusiliers. In the close up Carol posted you can make out two badges on the sergeants collar. As far as I am aware only two regiments had that arrangement, the other one was the Seaforth Highlanders and this soldier is not one of those.

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: These are men of the Royal Irish Rifles - probably the 2nd Battalion who were based at Phoenix Parks Barracks and Royal Hill Barracks in Dublin. My grandfather and his brother served with the Regiment. www.militaryartcompany.com/irish_regiments.htm
